body: A Brooklyn teen-ager was acquitted yesterday and another convicted of only the least serious charge against him in what prosecutors said was the bias-driven beating death of a homeless Ecuadorean immigrant in a Brooklyn park. After deliberating a day and a half in a monthlong trial, a jury in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn acquitted Steven Ruiz,
title: Youth Acquitted and Another Convicted of Lesser Charge in Immigrant's Fatal Beating

body: With a theatrical flourish, the issue of organized crime came to the fore yesterday in the trial of two teen-age cousins charged with killing an Ecuadorean man in a bias attack in Brooklyn last year. A defense lawyer, attacking the notion that the defendants' family is connected to organized crime, suddenly called on 20 of their relatives to rise
title: Mafia Issue Is Raised At Bias Trial In Brooklyn

body: On the night of Sept. 6, 1994, a 40-year-old homeless Ecuadorean immigrant named Manuel Aucaquizhpi was beaten to death with a baseball bat and other weapons in Dyker Beach Park in Brooklyn. The Brooklyn District Attorney and representatives of Hispanic rights groups described the beating, by a group of white teen-agers, as a savage, bias-driven
title: Two Youths Go on Trial In a Killing

body: A state Assistant Attorney General and a State Supreme Court law secretary were among the winners in last night's primary elections for Civil Court judgeships in New York City. While voters cast ballots for nominees for 15 Civil Court judgeships, only 5 were contested in the Democratic primary. There were no Republican candidates for judgeships. No
title: Law Secretary Wins Primary For Judgeship

body: Primary elections will be held tomorrow in New York City, with polls open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. Voters will cast ballots for nominees for 15 Civil Court judgeships and for district leader and delegates and alternates to the judicial convention. No primaries will be held in the Bronx or Staten Island. Only 5 of the 15 Civil Court judgeships are
title: Civil Court Nominees to Be Decided

title: PUBLIC INTEREST; Brooklyn Community Board Meetings

body: At Public School 204 in Dyker Heights on Thursday, Celia Rossi's second graders pored over their phonics workbooks. It was a typical first-day-of-school scene. And the number of students in Mrs. Rossi's class, 29, was typical of the larger, more crowded classes throughout Community School District 20, which covers Bay Ridge, Dyker Heights and Fort
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN SCHOOLS UP CLOSE; Larger Classes, Smaller Staffs

body: There are 15 New York City Civil Court seats up for election in November. Yet only five are being contested in next week's Democratic primary -- which means that many of the others will owe their jobs to party bosses who largely control who gets on the ballot. Unlike some elections in the past, this year's group of primary candidates is low on
title: Civil Court Choices

body: Alternate-side street parking regulations have never been among New York's more beloved traditions. But in some places at least, a measure of relief is on the way. An experiment that began in Bay Ridge to halve the time drivers must vacate parking spots to allow street cleaning was deemed a success and has been made permanent there. Other
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTHERN BROOKLYN; 90 Minutes That Shook . . . Street Parking?

body: For years, the board of Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School thought a key to greater success would be lower grades -- adding kindergarten through fourth to the school, which offers fifth through twelfth grades at its campus in Dyker Heights. But board members also feared that few parents of young children in the lower grades would be willing
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE/COBBLE HILL; Poly Prep Buys Woodward Park

body: An article last Sunday about Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, omitted part of the name of a statewide organization of private schools whose head commented on the Brooklyn school's changing demographics. The group is the New York State Association of Independent Schools.
title: Corrections

body: THE chapel at Poly Prep comes straight out of central casting (boys' school, old-line; jump-cut to summers in Quogue). There's the dark woodwork, the stiff-backed pews, the framed black-and-white photographs of alumni killed on the battlefields of World War II. One expects a plump and pink-faced chaplain, intoning something from the Book of Common
title: MAKING IT WORK; Retooling Poly Prep
